user_review: Hands down to the best ramen place in Montreal! I have been meaning to go there for almost a year but it never happened until today. I along with 2 other friends went over at Yokato Yokabai and as soon as we entered the restaurant we were greeted by loud "irasshaimase" and then had the best treat of we could get on a rainy winter day! We tried the ramen with gomami broth and chicken. The broth was simply unbelievable. All of us just loved it and were like "ah we wish we had more broth ..." The noodles was also great! Having lived in Japan for almost 6 years, I can vouch that outside of Japan, it would be pretty hard to find better ramen than this place. The decor, the ambience of the restaurant altogether makes it a perfect Japanese place! I would definitely go back to this ramen place with more friends :) Gotta try the other stuffs in the menu!

Got takeout here for my adoption birthday and it did not disappoint! The meat was perfect and the egg was really good with the broth. The noodles were also amazing, they stuck together a tiny bit so stir before you enjoy! Love that they have an option for extra seaweed and corn. Also got the karaage chicken entree to share and they were delicious.

Definitely a go-to for Ramen in Montreal! The entrance is a little hidden and off the main road, but that of itself kinda added to the ambiance of the restaurant. That being said, even arriving for a late dinner ~8 PM, there was a fair lineup and the entrance was packed of people trying to escape the cold and wait for their table. Luckily, you do have the opportunity to go through the menu and make your selections for broth/noodles/extras so the moment you're seated, your order is placed!I had opted for less salty tonkatsu broth, thick noodles, and extra pork. Given all the extras on top of the base cost, my order came to ~$13.50, which I thought was well worth the size and quality of the ingredients - just look at the thick cut of chasiu! I thought all the extra toppings definitely completed the bowl, but I think it would be nice if the standard variation had some of the staples like bamboo shoots and scallions. As well, each table had an assortment of extra seasoning to add in; my personal favourite was a chili garlic powder that I thought added a nice kick to a well-balanced broth (even as less salty). Overall, super solid ramen place with really speedy service! From the time. However, I do advise that wait times can be a little longer as its a small restaurant, and if you're going as a party of less than three you will likely be seated with strangers at tables, but turnover is very quick! Worth for a warm bowl of ramen during cold Montreal winters.

Very decent ramen! Finally a ramen that's not too salty in Montreal (and I've had many...). I would recommend it, the decor is nice, the food really good and the prices very reasonable! One tiny note on the fried chicken, it was a bit too deep fried for my taste but the taste was good.

My go to place for ramen in Montreal. Easily the best spot in town, and closest to Japanese taste. Broth is rich and creamy, a bit on the heavy side, but really flavourful.Service is excellent, all waiters and employees are nice.Recommended :Tonkotsu ramen (with my picks of lotus seed, full egg and a must have seaweed), Gobo fries and Karaage.

Visiting Montreal from Boston I had really low expectations for ramen. Yokato Yokabai really didn't hit the mark for me. Food: I got the tonkatsu with pork belly, corn, scallion, egg, spicy kara-miso. It was mediocre, lacked flavor. The broth should've been steaming hot, but it was close to lukewarm as if it was sitting for awhile and that's not okay to me. Price: I don't think the price is worth it for the quality of the food. First off if I want to make the ramen spicier why do I have to pay a extra $1. The starting price is $14.95 and extra add ons just didn't make the ramen worth the price. Service/Atmosphere: The service was mediocre and because we were sitting at the bar because there was no room it felt like we were neglected. They were also really specific about the amount of people in the party and sitting at specific tables. If you have three people you need to be sat in a 4 person booth even though you could fit in a 3 person booth. Also there's not a waiting area so be aware as you might have to wait outside of the building.Overall: I will not be coming back, it's just not worth it. It really put me off from trying other ramen shops in Montreal.

We went there because it had really good reviews and it was popular on Yelp. I personally expected more but the broth was too thick and oily. In addition, the noodles were hard in the middle and felt like they were a bit uncooked. Overall, place is ok but there are better places out there..

When it first opened a few years ago, it was similar to Ippudo! Now it's still good however we found that it was more expensive than before. I.e. adding 1$ for thick noodles and extra options. Preferred the tonkatsu soup base than the other option. However, place has expanded and they work jointly with Ichi Ichigo bar so we had a place quickly for big group.

This place was amazing! The food and service were both great, even when the restaurant was busy. The ramen builder has great options. We got the fried chicken both times and shared a ramen (just got extra noodles). The thick noodles are a must try!

I came here for lunch and the place was packed! From the outside it looked like the building was completely closed down, but it was actually spacious and really cute inside! The lunch menu is quite simple. You select what you want for your ramen from a small paper. I tried the pork in the traditional broth. It was absolutely delicious!!! I would have it again any day! I also tried the fried chicken as an appetizer and it was good. I would stick to ramen though. I highly recommend to try this place!!

Probably the best ramen shop in Montreal?Chicken karaage: doesn't need any Japanese mayo as it comes with its own sauce and white and black sesame seeds sprinkled on top.Gobo (burdock) fries: at first I thought it tasted like fried eggplant fries, but it's actually a Japanese root. Tastes ok, wouldn't order again.Sapporo Draft: fresh, crisp, cold, goes well with hot ramen.Ramen: ordered thin noodles tonkotsu soup ramen. The ramen was delicious. This is the only ramen shop I've seen offer chicken teriyaki as a topping instead of chashu. It was meh. But a nice alternative if you don't like the fattiness of chashu. I finished the ramen in about 2 minutes. Portion sizes aren't huge so be sure to order an appetizer or two. Note: default only gives you half an egg, full egg costs extra (boo)

Absolutely fabulous ramen restaurant! Authentic, rich, and delicious. Excellent service. Expect to wait but the ramen is well worth the wait.... trust me! I cleaned the bowl! In house noodles are amazing!! Also, they have matcha ice cream annnd fabulous cocktails! Treat yourself!!

This place is super dope. You have to look out for it or you'll walk right past just like I did. The service here is amazing and they get everything done very fast! There are tons of seating but apparently not enough as they still get people waiting at the door - I get it, a good ramen place in Montreal? That's kind of hard to come by?You can choose your broth, meat and toppings + any sides all written down on a piece of paper with your name - makes it super easy for them to give you your exact bowl and bill especially in a larger group. Love the organization here!I had the tonkatsu + pork belly with thicccc noodles and let me tell you - that was some good noodz. Even coming from Markham and Toronto where there's an aUtHeNtIc ramen shop every corner, this was up there on my list. The broth was creamy and the pork belly .... wow!!! I don't enjoy eating pork often but this place does it right. Super thick and TWO big pieces of pork, crispy edges and soft middle. Drool worthy just typing about it!The noodles had a great chewy texture as well. Everything was perfect about this meal except for the way it sat in my stomach after - being somebody who doesn't eat out often + doesn't eat a lot of oily/greasy foods, I immediately felt nauseous after devouring it and ran to the bathroom TWICE to wretch. :( I guess it had something to do with the creamy broth or the fatty content of the chashu. Do I regret eating the meal? HELLLL NAH! 10/10 would do again.

Definitely one of the best ramen places I've had the opportunity to try. Visiting in Montreal I tried to hunt down as many different cuisines as I could. I was very excited to find this place especially thanks to all the high reviews. Walking in, we were greeted fairly quickly and had our orders taken. They allowed us to customize our ramen with everything that we wanted. The food came after a short period of time and you can definitely tell that a lot of time and care was placed into making the dish. The broth was absolutely perfect, I asked for low salt and even with that you could really taste all the flavor. The pork was perfectly cooked and tender and the noodles were perfectly made as well. I was very satisfied with my ramen and I would definitely return here if I came to visit Montreal again!

Tonkotsu ramen was amazing. Broth was clear tasting and flavorful and not super salty. The noodles were thin but had a bite to it. The pork belly just melts in your mouth. The egg was soft boiled and slightly runny. A good bowl of ramen indeed. The place isn't huge and seating can be cramped. We were seated in the corner and with our big winter coats, it can be hard to fit ourselves in. There's usually a line out the door but we decided to skip the dinner line and opt to come back the next morning for lunch and the line was a lot shorter on Sunday noon compared to Saturday night. Servers were friendly but it was a bit hard to get service or anyone to pay attention to us. Maybe cause we were in the corner or maybe they were busy but we had to sit around for awhile before we can flag someone down. We ordered the yuzu ice cream because I think they make their ice cream in house. They had other flavors like sake too. The yuzu was a strong yuzu flavor and it was more of a sorbet than ice cream. It was a nice way to end our meal with something sour and refreshing.

Best ramen in Montreal! Very trendy spot that gets crowded really quickly, so come before peak hours! The thin noodles are excellent and if you like spicy definitely add in some spicy miso. The pork is so good here and a great addition. The portions for the Kara-age are also fairly good so it likely it isn't necessary to get a portion for each person.

My first ramen experience and I believe I chose quite well. It was fantastic! So let me explain the lack of ramen in my life- simply put, I'm vegetarian and horribly allergic to food additives, preservatives, chemicals- so with that combo, you don't find many- or really any edible ramen broths anywhere! .Here not only do they promote natural healthy ingredients, there were two veggie options! The gomami was soy milk and sesame based- the other was kombu- natural msg- so of course I went with the gomami which was made to emulate tonkatsu pork broth which is their non- veg option. I can't begin to describe the rich soothing flavors that made the perfect base for home made ramen and accompanying vegetables. My boyfriend had the gomami broth with chicken and loved it every bit as much as I did. We also ordered the burdock fries and while they were interesting not amazing, they got my food allergies going quickly. Cravings for this place may make me come back to Montreal much sooner than I imagined!

When you go to Japan and gain 10lbs within 2 weeks- you know what authentic Japanese food is. Yokato Yokabai is the closest flavour you'll get from Japan. Forget Kinton Ramen, THIS is your spot right here. Yokato will provide you a sheet where you can have your ramen custom made. From the level of salt to the thickness of your ramen- you got it the way you want it. Ichigo Ichie is an izakaya located right beside the ramen shop. Go there to grab a bite while waiting to get seated because Yokato does not accept reservation. Two birds one stone. You'll get two dinner in one seating.

Best ramen I've had in Montreal... maybe in all of Canada.  I just came back from Tokyo earlier this year and I must say that this is very similar to the ramens I ate there.  The house beer on draft was also a perfect pairing.  Look no further if you're craving ramen in Montreal.

Japanese cuisine (and culture) fascinates me greatly and when the opportunity came up to enjoy some ramen in a place like this I jumped on the offer. The place is small and you'll quickly want to take off your clothes as the place felt like a steam house. We opted to dine in Ichigo and try out a few of their menu items (also avoid all the heat!) but I wanted to specifically review the ramen I had.The menu options are simple, you get a paper and pencil and you order your ramen to your own discretion. Ramen here is hakata style. Hakata is a district in Fukuoka City, the biggest city on Kyushu and the style of ramen from there is universally recognized as the standard version of tonkotsu. Hakata Ramen is usually topped with chashu, egg, scallion, sesame seeds and pickled ginger. I didn't want to stray from the culture too much so my ramen soup was basically thick noodles, broth, chashu, scallions and egg. I garnished my soup with some seaweed (I'll get more next time!) and a few items provided at the table.The soup was fantastic. The broth was delicious and rich and made me more and more addicted as I tried to inhale my soup as slowly as possible. The seaweed was a perfect change of pace. The chashu (pork belly) was sublime and literally melted in the mouth. What a soup! Reading from reviews from people who had the real thing in Japan say it's very close to the real thing. This is a great compliment and I'm grateful to enjoy this soup on the other side of the planet. Service was great. We ate at the bar and our host was friendly. A few drinks were had, some were on the house.  The price/value for this kind of meal doesn't apply. I strongly recommend this place, I'll definitely be back.Gochisosama deshita!

Try for the first time this gonami noodle soup (the one with yellow thick broth). The taste is better than at other ramen place like Misoya, Kinton... Price with taxes and tips is high about 18$ since it is located on Plateau Mont Royal. My cousin took the vegetarien broth which seems to be normal.

This summer I was on a major ramen kick! After making several broths at home I wanted to compare mine to the pros. i completed the NYC trip I went up to Montreal to try out Yokato Yokabai which had a great reputation. I arrived wrote down my customized order and sat patiently like a little kid waiting for his ice cream bowl!! This place had a lot of hype to it and I was excited! The tonkotsu broth was my first venture into bliss. I added some spicy kara-miso, some bamboo, the obligatory egg, Nori, green onions, tried the 'thick noodles" and the Cha-shu! Let me try to explain how freaking good this was! All you really need to do is look at the picture of the broth i took to understand. That being said, I can tell you that its was one of the creamiest broths I've had in a long time. The broth attached itself to the noodles in such a way that every slurp was pure heaven. Not overtly beefy or fatty, the Tare simply balance this bowl out to perfection. I do like spice and although they did not have any chili oil the spicy miso bomb was insane.. My obligatory egg was the perfect 5 min egg that coddled the noodles with yolk goodness! Their Cha-Shu was a bit different then i have seen in the past as it was meat forward and less fatty then most. This did not prove to be an issue as it simply melted in my mouth after one or two chews. The chewy thick noodles in my first round were exactly as advertised. When I got my kae-dama of thin noodles, for the end of my bowl, I was once again transported to ramen bliss. So it might not surprise some of you that a second bowl had to be ordered! I added some corn as the substitute to my egg and slurped away! Once I finished, complete satisfaction overcame me. Best bowl or ramen this summer. So there are three rooms, the bar room had booze and high top tables. the kitchen room has individual counters that are shared but no booze is served in this room and finally the third room is the evening service. Their broth is simmered for 12 hours and all ingredients are totally and certified organic. this place is very popular and does not take reservations so choose wisely when you go. Staff was friendly and helpful, food was very good, noise level moderate in the kitchen room and loud in the bar room.  I was there for lunch so i cannot speak about the downstairs room but with its high ceilings I'd say not an issue. I did find street parking but at night might be an issue.. Price point was a none issue as it was a superior meal! Run don't walk to Yokato Yokabai Ramen!!!

Awesome.  Just as the fellow Yelpers called it.  I was lucky to get in without waiting which seems to be abnormal for Yokato.  By the time I left, there was a line out the door.  Given it was in the teens for temps, there are some hardcore ramen lovers out there.  Now for the ramen, there was nothing negative to say here; it was simply one of the best I've had around the world.  The tonkotsu was superb and the add ons all complement each other.  The staff were attentive and once you fill out the card for your order, the wait was minimal and out comes the ramen.  If you go, go early to avoid longer wait times.

I've had probably a dozen of the best ramen places in the U.S., but this shop still really stood out to me. My boyfriend and I came here when we were visiting Montreal since I was craving ramen and this definitely hit the spot. We both ordered the Tonkotsu ramen which, although wasn't the best I've had, was quite delicious. What really stood out to me though were their cocktails - the green tea and mango cocktails were amazing! Although it was a bit pricey for ramen, I would recommend this to anyone.Pros(+) Options on the menu: I really like it when ramen places give you options on the noodles, broth and toppings. (+) Cocktails: Already raved about these, I haven't really seen matcha cocktails anywhere else(+) It was easy to get seating for two when we went around lunch hour

I went to this place with a lot of expectations but I was hugely disappointed. I ordered Ramen with Gomami broth and Pork Belly meat. It looked good at first sight. However, it is not up to the mark when I tasted for the following reasons:1. The broth was at room temperature. I told the waiter and they brought me additional broth in a separate bowl, but that was over-salted. These people did not even bother to taste it before serving. 2. I was expecting pork-belly slices, instead, I got one that looked like minced meat. They probably mixed up the order.3. I had to pay $18 (little things add up quickly plus tax) and additional tip. For this price, I would expect better food and service.4. Service: They could use additional people. It looked like there is just one person taking care of everybody. Nobody even bothered to come in between and ask if everything was ok. It was all rushed and there was a huge line waiting outside. I am not sure why people are crazy about this place. Probably it was a one time miss.
Phenomenal Ramen! The soup base of tonkotsu is creamy and complex in taste! Love it!Waited in line for less than 30 mins on a Tuesday night, not bad.

I had friend coming from Winnipeg and we were looking for a good ramen restaurant. As we went through friends and internet recommendations, we found this highly rated nice place in the sector of Plateau Mont-Royal. I had the most delicious miso tonkotsu ramen there. Everything felt so authentique, you know the owners care about their art as everything had a nice presentation and excellent taste. Also had the karaage which I would definitely recommend to anyone trying as the chicken was crazy tender with a good crunchy crisp on the outside. The service was quick, efficient and the staff was super friendly.

The broth was too rich for my liking, although the ramen was flavourful. Because the Mtl ramen game isn't so strong, I'd say that this ramen joint is one of the best in town. Service was good, great ambiance, nothing out of the ordinary. The drinks were good too. There's always a line, and I won't go out of my way to eat here, but I highly recommend everyone to try. It really depends on personal taste.

I ordered the broth and it wasn't as flavorful as the other ones I've tried before. The egg isn't the best either; yolk was slightly overcooked. The only saving grace for me was the pork, which was absolutely incredible.

Ramen was fine, but I don't think I would go back.  Had to wait about 40 minutes to get seated.  The service was ok, but we had to wait forever to get napkins and they forgot to bring the ice cream I ordered at the end (the ice cream was actually delicious).  As to the ramen, their special broth is good, but the rest of the meal was average.  My wife makes ramen from time to time and hers is just as good.

I went on a Friday night around 8 and the place was packed and we had to wait for like an hour! I had the vegetable broth ramen with chicken, it tasted pretty good. It's a great place to take a date to because of the warm ambience. I cant say much about the authenticity of this place since i haven't had a lot of Japanese food.Update: the pork broth ramen is very good. Thick broth. But they do not offer thick noodles after 6pm

We arrived right as it opened at noon and were seated right away. After we ordered the place filled up very quickly and a line started to build, so you can tell this place is very popular. The order card was fun so you get to personalize your ramen. There was a good assortment of drinks and ramuné, which is a really fun Japanese soda (get the classic "original" or "grape")! I recommend going to the restroom while your there so you get to pass where they make their noodles downstairs!The matcha ice-cream was the perfect intensity of matcha flavor. Will definitely recommend to a friend and try to go back asap to try more of the food there.

By far the best and most authentic ramen in Montreal! It's the closest thing to what I experienced in Japan. The atmosphere is inspired and cozy, and the service is friendly. Try the Gomami Ramen. It's a delicious, lighter option. The Chicken Karaage will blow your mind.

I've yet to experience better tasting ramen than the one I've had here. Better than I've had in LA, Chicago, or ATL.Maybe one day when I go to Japan, then it might be topped, but their ramen was amazing.

Solid ramen spot. The line was a bit long and the place to sit down is quite small so be prepared for that. I will say though, the broth was really nice and so was the pork belly that I got in my ramen, so I definitely enjoyed it. I also got the chicken karaage which was great! 4 stars because it wasn't TOTALLY worth the wait.

Still the best ramen in Montreal! I brought the cuz here and it was about 1000C in the restaurant. We decided to eat next door at Ichi go Ichie. As you can order ramen from the Yokato menu plus whatever you want from the Ichigo menu. The hakata style ramen is creamy deliciousness and the chashu pork you could be a toothless man and still enjoy to the max! An amazing dining experience!

This is a great ramen restaurant I always come back to. My personal fave is the pork tonkatsu. The broth is clean and flavourful very porky. The cha siu is thickly cut but melts in your mouth. They provide toppings on the side which was really nice. Ginger, sesame, and garlic ~ really made it a better dish. Highly recommend to all ramen lovers out there !

The ramen is really fantastic here! The tonkutsu broth was milky and I love that I got the option to have less salt in the menu. Super tasty, good portion, great atmosphere but be ready to wait in line. They don't take reservations and on a rainy Tuesday night we waited about 20 to 25 minutes to be seated. But definitely worth the wait!!!

Now I'm no uber ramen aficionado but I have been to quite a few and have tried enough ramen bowls to determine the good from the "meh" and I'll start by saying that this place is a definite YESSSSS.The decor of this restaurant is awesome and gives off a very "homey" feel with the decor and the art.  The menu itself is very simple and has you just selecting what you want and passing it off to the waiter. I opted for the Tonkotsu broth with extra pork belly and green onions and oh my was it delicious.  They have an assortment of condiments you can add (fried garlic, hot oil, pickled ginger and ground sesame) and all of it really helps enhance the already tasty flavor.  The broth itself was very rich and I could tell that they were simmering that pork broth for a LONG time by the flavor.  The place was bustling and even though we got there RIGHT at the openning (noon in this case on a Saturday), the interior was already packed (though there were seats in the back room).  Overall if you're in the area and are a lover of ramen definitely give this place a go!

Restaurant:The place was packed at 10pm on a Saturday night because it is one of the only asian places open at that time. We ended up being served at the ramen "bar" because the wait line for the "restaurant" (full menu) had a wait time of 35min. Note this place is divided in two rooms, ramen bar and then the full restaurant. Food: Ramen was ok, not the greatest. Ive had betterService: excellent Restaurant Aesthetics n Music: Great place for dates, the music at the ramen was a tad loud but not enough that you cant hear your partner, the music selection was bomb, contemporary rnb/hip hop mix

This was one of the best ramen places I've been to. The menu is very customizable, which is great for people who have dietary constraints or are picky. I'm from the states and usually the broths are all pork based but this place had the option of vegetable and chicken broth. The portions are great- not too much to the point of being uncomfortably full. I usually encounter this problem with ramen. Our server was also very attentive and nice. The walls are also very cool and the place looks much bigger than it appears.

This doesn't compare to anything in Japan. Waited about 30 minutes to be seated at a bar style table. Food came pretty quickly. Downside to all this is that you cannot drink alcohol on this side of the restaurant. I wouldn't be desperate to come here again.

This is delicious but I wouldn't say I am raving about it. The pork cha-shu was deliciously made, the best I have ever had, but the rest of it was okay. For the price I am paying, to have to pay extra for corn, or a full egg or all the other items you need (bamboo shoots), sort of turns me off. The wait wasn't that long, about 5 minutes but it does get packed.

I've been here multiple times so I believe I can give a pretty reliable review. The restaurant itself is tiny, limited seatings, long waits but you know what, that's how it is in Japan and I love that authenticity. You even customize your ramen on a piece of paper, which I love because it accommodates to people's preferences. All my visits have been a rollercoaster. I remember a few times where the ramen was delicious; flavourful tonkotsu broth, amazing toppings you can add for free (sesame seeds, sesame oil, ginger and garlic chips) and even the smaller side dishes are tasty. I highly recommend getting their karaage, the topping they put on top of the fried chicken is unreal. Prices have stayed pretty consistent but I find it pretty expensive for ramen. It's about $15 if you keep all the basics without adding any extra. However, there are 2 extras I urge everyone to get: kara-miso (if you like spicy) and thick noodles. There's a catch since thick noodles are only available for lunch, which is so unfortunate. I had the regular noodles and they just don't taste as fresh. Lately, I find that the more I go, the more disappointed I get, which upsets me because I used to love it here. What's inconsistent here is the broth. Tonkotsu is pretty creamy in general which I appreciate, but some visits the broth is too thick and others it's perfect. I then did have one bad experience where the tonkotsu broth tasted too much like sea salt and it overpowered everything else. I also tried their yuzu ice cream and it's a must!Now, when Yokato Yokabai originally opened, you could only eat ramen on that side of the establishment. Now that it's a busier restaurant, they accommodate customers by opening a room on the Ichigo Ichie side as long as they did not reserve ahead, and that is a smart solution to the long lines, while still keeping the "first come first serve" basis. So in general, I believe everyone should come here at least once to try it out. I might be harsh because I've had amazing tonkotsu ramen here, but it just hasn't been the same lately. I still give Yokato Yokabai 4 stars because they do stand out from other ramen restaurants and they have unique perks. It kills me that I can't give 5 stars!

Probably some of the best ramen I've ever had. Yokato Yokabai is located on a corner but its entrance is pretty inconspicuous, but its food is quite the opposite and an absolute standout. It is definitely worth a visit whether you are a local looking for a ramen fix or a tourist trying out some of the amazing restaurants in Montreal.We started off with the Karaage (japanese fried chicken). It was crunchy, juicy and the chicken was very tender. It was topped off with some sort of green onion and shiitake relish-like condiment that added a slightly sour kick to it, which was interesting. Although the Karaage was great the ramen is (obviously) what this place is known for. All the ramen is made in-house and if you walk down to the washroom there is a wide window that allows you to look into the ramen-making room (and sometimes if you're lucky you'll see someone in there making the magic happen). And you can definitely taste the difference. I got the thin noodles and they were firm upon putting them in your mouth, yet soft on bite. It is hard to describe but they gave the perfect amount of resistance in your mouth. The tonkotsu broth, which you can adjust the salt level of, was pretty creamy and rich. It wasn't overpowered with salt or flavour and although pretty heavy from the dairy in it, it was relatively balanced. The chashu was by far the best I've ever had. It was extremely soft and tender and had a nice smokey flavour to it (and not overcooked, which is a common mistake). There was a perfect mix of fat and meat, and even the fat was very soft.

We had chicken ramen and pork soup based ramen. The broth was very delicious and not as overly salty as the traditional ramen. We added bamboo, extra seaweeds, lotus roots and eggs as toppings. The place is tiny and we waited about 10minutes before sit in.This restaurant had decent ramen I recommend it. The only downside is that the restaurant is very packed and service is a bit slow.
Years later, still a regular. Favourite Ramen spot in Montreal. Make sure to order their Fried Chicken as an appetizer and ask for extra sauce on top!!

In my humble opinion the best ramen place in Montreal. Is it the same as a bowl in Japan? No, but it is the closest I have eaten here in Montreal, probably. I also love the accommodating nature of their ordering; quite Muslim and vegan friendly.And I must mention the gobo fries. Ah, my love gobo a.k.a burdock root fries. From the cut to the seasoning, they are perfect and a must-order side dish. You will not regret. If you like chicken, go for the karaage as well. Deliciously juicy and savoury.
Amazing, hot sake, cold beer. Recommend the duck and the roasted brussels sprouts! Small place but the food comes out pretty quick!

Entrance is just around the corner on Drolet as you walk up Rue Rachel, building no. 4185... right next to a white residential car garage... not very conspicuous especially in the evening... and when it's located in the residential neighborhood. If you still can't find it, look for people waiting and standing on the sidewalk.There is something about the ramen here at Yokato Yokabai... it was late, nearly closing time actually, and we couldn't help ourselves from devouring bowl after bowl of Tonkotsu ramen. Three bowls per person if someone was counting... were we hungry, maybe... was it that good, certainly... something in Canada's water that makes tasty ramen broth, who knows.

I was really excited to try this restaurant since it has so many good reviews. The place is small and cozy - You must arrive early if you don't want to wait!! I waited about 15 min for 2 persons on a saturday at around 6 pm.There is not really a menu. It's actually a small piece of paper where you choose what you want. The variety is very limited so don't expect a huge selection. You actually get the chance to customize you ramen (Vegetarien/Pork broth, large/thin noodle, etc.)So I took the chicken karaage as an appetizer and the tonkotsu ramen (with thin noodle, pork broth, cha-shu, scallion and half egg).Karaage- A little bit dry. (I think the chicken was made before we order)- Really crunchy which is nice.Tonkotsu Ramen- Noodle: It was excellent, it has a nice texture to it and it soaked really well the broth.- Broth: It's rich and creamy but the taste is just decent. - Chasu: Extremely good. It's so tender.Nothing to complain about the services!OverallDecent meal but with an incredible cha-shu! The broth deceived me the most. I might have expected too much!

Three stars because it wasn't a "oh yeahhh" tasting experience PLUS portion received to dollar spent is not harmonious. The soup itself is on the heavy/rich side compared to pho but gotta admit it has a good kick to it and the pork belly in this soup makes you smile inside. Had this ramen soup for the first time and picked this place because it literally shines with positive reviews and generous stars on the Internet. For $22 with tax and tip for a medium size bowl, I didn't see the value nor other incentive to come back. I'll stick with my pho. Beau, bon, pas chère as they say plus no line up to wait to get inside a small dark resto with no windows. Odd and a little sad IMO. Not for me but please go ahead and try to satisfy your curiosity if you're new to this. You might find out that you're more a ramen person than pho, who knows. As one of the two stars reviews put it and which I liked a lot: "it's not you, it's me" :))

Delicious Karaage, and the ramen is toothsome with the pork belly melting in your mouth.  Broth is also very flavorful.  I marked the option for medium salt, and it wasn't too salty.I wanted to let all you yelpers know that even though it says no alcohol on yelp, there is a full bar.  Don't ask me exactly how it works, but apparently there are two restaurants that share the same space.  You get the one menu you mark with a pen and a separate bar menu.  It's only one check, so very easy.  Highly recommended.

This place is one of my fave places for ramen. You can customize your ramen according to your taste and they have a few choices or appetizers. My fave is the gobo fries. The best is the spicy broth with chasu pork (so tender). I wouldn't recommend this place if you're with a big group of friends, as places are limited and it is hard combine the seats for 4 or more people. We waited 2 hours once because we were 8 people and they had to wait for some tables to clear up at the same time. Overall, would definitely recommend this place.

The tonkatsu noodle was great and the broth very flavourful. Tho I was pretty disappointed with the waiting time once seated (it was about 20 min) and wished they gave more noodle... i am always hungry tho haha!

I've been in search of a good ramen for a while, tried many ramen places in the world and I can tell you it's one of the best ramens I've ever had. The tonkatsu ramen is rich and creamy, the pork is perfectly balanced between fat and meat. The only down side is the wait, we waited an hour to be seated.

Very nice, cozy and unique setting. We ordered the fried squids , fried chicken, chickens veggie and pork belly tonkotsu noodles soup. Noodles are fresh, soups very tasty and great selections of appetites . Love their atmosphere and very sweet friendly  attentive customer service from a young lady Sue A. Highly recommend this place.

A bowl of perfection at its finest.You know it's good when the line is out the door and around the corner on a Wednesday night at 8PM. I walked around hoping the line would die down and at 8:30PM it was still a half hour wait!Yokato Yokabai has a very simple check off menu of 4 sides, 3 kinds of ramen, and 4 types of ice cream, with specials of ordering 3 items/$1.50 off and 4 items/$3 off. English on one side and French on the other.I got the tonkotsu (13.95) with kara miso (spicy) (1), pork, a whole egg (0.75), and corn (0.75). This is the only place I have found to have absolutely perfect slices of pork, thick, fatty, and meaty as well. The broth was milky and creamy, with all the fat and collagen emulsified into an amazing soup. The kara miso was a great addition adding color, flavor, and complexity to the broth, but I think the chili oil can suffice in that regards. The garlic oil is great for all those garlic lovers out there, including myself. There was pretty much meat in every bite! The thin noodles were perfect in this kind of heavy ramen and I think with Montreal's weather, does great to warm the belly and soul.Not the best at seating since there were about 4-6 seats throughout the 30 seat restaurant empty. Even by the time I left at 9:45PM there were still people waiting in line to get seated! Stools have a cubby underneath for your stuff but generally there is no place to hang your coat. Water is self serve on the tables and service is busy between two waiters (my corn was forgotten). Definitely checkout the bathroom art while you're there.Not sure about the alcohol vs non-alcohol section but based on other Yelpers apparently you have to sit at the bar to be served alcohol.

Hands down the best ramen I've ever had in Montreal. And I LOVE ramen. Everything is cooked perfectly and has so much flavor. The broth isn't overly salted like most places and noodles are cooked just right. The pork belly is simply amazing. It melts in your mouth! You can also customize your ramen the way you want to (green onions, eggs, and any other side you want to add). The extra toppings that you can add also give this place it's uniqueness. Plus the restaurant is super nice and staff are very friendly and accommodating. I recommend everyone to try this place at least once. I know I'll be coming back for sure!

TLDR: one of the best ramen joints in the world (we would know). We live in Toronto and are lucky to have some of the best ramen in the world (Santouka, Sansotei, etc). In addition, we've visited Japan several times eating at the top ramen restaurants in the world. We can say with confidence that Yokato Yokabai is among the best.We ordered the tonkatsu with pork belly, regular salt, thin noodles. This is classic ramen at its best. You can tell from the intense depth of flavour that no corners have been cut in what is sure to be an insanely laboriously process. The pork belly is the one departure from tradition - and it works! Instead of the usual Cha Siu salty preparation, they opt for a more modernized caramelization. The result is a pork belly that melts in your mouth with a slight hint of sweetness. The broth is creamy but not heavy. FYI wait is long both for a seat and for your meal. Don't come in a rush. Highly recommend 10/10

Listen here closely , I've been to Japan and I know what real ramen is . This place is at 90% close to be the same as the the one in Japan . the quality of the food is amazingly good . the chicken taste really good . It was hard for me on eat some well made chicken in Montreal for the past 10 years and I finally found the place , it's tender juicy and flavourful!
Great food, service and ambiance. I even love the music! Ramen is to die for but everything I've had was delicious.

Yokato Yokabai's ramen is foodgasm inducing. I've been to this place like 10 times and it always blows me away. Every single aspect of their ramen is amazing. It is however a bit pricey in the sense that you're paying roughly about 20$ for a medium sized ramen. In theory it might seem a bit crazy, none the less their food is amazing. It's a place where you go to enjoy a Japanese classic from time to time and bring your closest friends. Like a precious secret.The atmosphere is very calming and relaxing even when it's packed on a Friday afternoon. The wooden benches aren't the most comfortable form of seating, but it works with the aesthetic and the soothing environment of the restaurant.

Best ramen place in my mind compare to mostly all  other Montreal's ramen place , I have to say their izakaya add some points too, if I only order ramen , i feel boring to not have other food accompany with , but their izakaya taste good too . They have 3 area which I don't like it , ramen only area, izakaya only area and mix area ....... wth , and no reservation only wait in line ..... and mix area always full . 45 mins waiting period is too long for me , I don't like to wait when I go eat , it broke up my excitement. So I go by chances only when I don't need to wait so long , :p but it's a good place worth to try .

I'm not a huge fan of ramen but this is probably the best ramen you can find in Montreal. I have been to Japan before and this is the closest in terms of taste. Soup is flavourful however texture-wise, it isnt as thick as most tonkatsu broth served in Japan. Noodles had a slight chew to them but could be chewier. Pork belly tasted good, it wasnt dry but didnt have enough of that melt-in-your-mouth effect i'm looking for. we also had the Char siu don and it tasted amazing, the way the fat was mixed into the rice - simply delicious.

I have to be honest, I was expecting amazing ramen and it was pretty mediocre. While I loved the atmosphere of both sides of the restaurant (the traditional sit down vs their tapas bar), the food wasn't anything special. I thought it was fun to customize your own bowl with the forms and pencils at the table and the food was presented nicely however the soup resembled the smell of manure... I had hoped for much more considering the hype it gets!

We wrapped up our new year trip in Montreal with, of course, ramen for lunch. First we went to Ramen-Ya, and found out that it was still closed for the new year, so we looked for another Japanese place nearby, and we found this gem, Yokato Yokabai!Firstly, you'd be asked if you wanted to consume alcohol. If so, you'd be seated in the bar section. The lunch menu was very simple with a handful of appetizers and two types of ramen, Tonkatsu and Kira-miso which you can choose to go with either chicken or pork. You can order from a piece of menu on the table and customize your ramen. We decided to get with the normal ramen which has regular saltiness. The broth was amazing. We also ordered gobo to go along with their fruit beer, Ichiko Ale. I personally never had gobo root before, so it was very interesting.Don't forget to check out the artworks along the way to the bathroom downstairs!I would recommend this place to anyone who's in search of good ramen in Montreal.

Good (but small)bowl of ramen.I would skip any add-ons for your first bowl. I would rather have a side than adding 2 strips of pork for 3$The soup was a 3 star, but what makes it a 4 is how everything, the decor to the cleanliness is on point.

I love Japanese noodle and once search for it in Montreal and found this place. I say this is a Good one but i had better, but having the condiment like fried garlic & others on the table for seasoning was such a big help.

THE FOOD IS MIND BLOWING; THIS IS A MUST TRYPROS:* simple ordering (checklist for make your own ramen) == no mistakes!* aesthetically pleasing taste* mind blowing food -- seriously, the pork belly MELTs in your mouth in the best way possible; tonkotsu broth is thick and tasty; I'm not sure what they do with the eggs, but they're phenomenal* portion sizes are generous, and you can add extras for relatively cheap* saw some people ordering the fried chicken + other apps, and they look goodCONS:* although the sizes are generous, bowls are $12 or so; definitely not an everyday eatery* not a huge menu. come here for ramen (or pork katsu), maybe get a snack on the side * servers aren't tooo friendly, had to grab their attention a few timesOVERALL:Definitely a delicious place and you won't be disappointed. Come for the food, not the service or a "steal" of a meal

THE BEST ramen I have ever had. Broth- At first I was worried that there was not a lot of broth, but after one sip I understood why. Their broth is twice as thick as most other places! The amount they give is just perfect, after finishing the entire bowl it is just enough too satiate, but not too much as to make you queasy with the heaviness. Could definitely taste the pork bone. Normal salt was very savory. Pork cha shui- melt in your mouth, perfect flavor. Egg- I cannot get over how good the egg is.  It has just the right amount of the slightly sweet flavor of Japanese soy sauce. I asked and they said it was marinated, first time I ever encountered a ramen place that puts so much thought into the egg!Noodles- only component that I would not give full marks on. I prefer noodles more chewy, and theirs, while not limp like many other ramen places, are not quite powerful enough. Would suggest adding a bit of salt to the dough and/or kneading it longer to perfect the noodles. Other condiments- seaweed was so good. Added bamboo which was also good. Chili oil on the table not super spicy, ended up adding about 5 spoons. Sake ice cream- first time ever having something like this! Super interesting flavor, but I felt it was a bit too icy and not creamy enough.

After a long night of watching of youtube of ramen houses in new york I just had a bad craving for a bowl of Tonkatsu ramen. The craving for Tonkatsu soup base, that's creamy and thick that coats inside your mouth when you drink the broth. Seeing the ramen noodles coated with the broth, the moment I slurp into my mouth is that warm feeling like being in bed with a warm blanket in a cold winter day.I went to a few Ramen houses in montreal and none of them were tummy warm satisfaction. Until I located this hidden ramen house on corner of Drolet and St-Denis called Yokato Yokabai. When I first passed by the Ramen house there wasn't a big sign but lots of great drawing on the front door. I arrive there on a snowy day afternoon lunch there was no line up. The moment I walked inside, was a warm feeling of smell in the air. They greet us in japanese and welcome us do we wanna have alcohol or not. Cause if you want to drink alcohol you have to go to Ichigo Ichie japanese pub connected to the Yokato Yokabai. No drinks for me.The interior was really traditional Japanese pub. Matches well with the menu. You gotta see the bathroom!! First you gotta find it in the basement.So I sat right next to the opened well ventilation open kitchen where the action is. I think I had the best seat in the house for person like me.You order your meal on a small piece of paper that offers Side dishes, main soups plus extra sides and Desserts. The waiter explain how to order very nice of him. I order a tonkatsu broth with chasu 13.95$ and whole egg 0.75$ more with extra green scallions.Side dish of fried crispy chicken "Karaage".The waiter put the order in, and I watch the chef start frying the golden chicken. In 6 mins the order comes to the table. It smells wonderful. I'm gonna wait for my Ramen to come first cause the karaage is still hot.The karaage looked really crispy. It was covered with grated radish and a ponzu sauce (I think). The first bite I took was a big crunch and juice of the chicken thighs pieces. Wow!! It's like eating a juicy chip in my mouth and proper seasoned. Very properly fried to perfection. Good work!! Other places only had little bit of crunch and no seasoning.After my first bite of karaage i was in another world, then the tonkatsu arrived. The presentation was very nice delightful and eye appetizing. The broth looks really creamy.It smelled very meaty like pork meat, pork cartilage and chicken-bones been boiling over the hot stove for 6 hours. The smell opened up my appetite like a hot apple pie out of the oven. Here comes the moment of truth, the taste factor. First thing gotta go for the the creamy broth. Big slurp from bowl to mouth. That creamy broth!! Is wonderfully coats inside my taste buds. I never had such creamy delicious tonkatsu broth in Montreal. It's gotta be that tablespoon of pork fat they put in the broth right before serving makes it so mouth pleasant. The broth coats well the noodle when you eat it the noodle it bounce or dances in the mouth. Very delicious. In the bowl of Ramen includes egg, onions, black fungus root (I think) and 2 thick slice of chasu with some fat on it. Let me liberate how they prepare the chasu, they boil the pork belly in the tonkatsu until tender. Then they take it out and cool down for several hours. Cut into thick slices before service. Right before serving they put the meat heaven in a toaster to warm it, after a few mins they take it out and BLOW TORCH they pork belly is until caramelize and bit of charcoal. That's what makes the pork taste so amazing!! You could see how passionate I am about a good bowl of Ramen.Alright back to the Bowl of Tonkatsu, the second element of heavenly. Is the egg!! The yolk is so perfectly cooked to medium. The yolk is liquidy but firm and it was marinated just enough flavour of the soya sauce. At the end I had a green tea ice cream and a SAKE ice cream. The green tea taste like any other, but the sake....wow!! It's a homemade sake ice cream it helped a lot to cut down the fatty broth. It's a really good match.At the end, I was a satisfied customer!! With a full stomach and a warm feeling after the meal. I highly suggest this place! On a rainy snowy day go out and grab a warm bowl of Ramen!!!

Presently the only ramen shop I'd recommend in Montreal. Not only it is authentic, it is gooood. Even my Japanese friend, a visiting scholar who describes himself as a "ramen-freak", approves of Yokato Yokabai.The menu is straightforward:  - choice of broth (pork or miso) - meat (chicken or pork) or vegeterian - toppings (green onion, seaweed, egg)Extras can be ordered, and saltiness can be tweaked - a nice accomodation for e.g. health conscious clients. Then there's sidedishes. We tried the fried chicken (karaage), the most popular, and found it great. The ramen, however, is on a whole other level. All the secrets are in the broth. Hakata-style ramen is renowned for its pork (tonkotsu)-based soup. It is thick, opaque, rich and delicious. Different jars of condiments are also available: fried garlic, sesame, picked ginger, etc.Speaking of options, I heard that Yokato Yokabai now offers cold (hiyashi) noodles! A great choice during summer to avoid sweating extra buckets.To cool down, there are also desserts. We had yuzu ice cream, the only item we disliked that evening. It was initially delicious, but yuzu was so potent that my tastebuds were cringing at the end. I'll definitely opt for green tea next time.Finally, to encourage all fans of ramen to visit this restaurant, I wrote a haiku:Delicious ramenFrom Yokato YokabaiSummer in a bowl

This place was worth the wait even in the middle of Montreal winter (visited in March 2019). We haven't stopped talking about this ramen - amazing vegan option, which was much appreciated. Also a cool atmosphere inside.

Seriously this ramen is fan-f'ing-tastic. I've enjoyed ramen from all around the world, including Ippudo in Japan, Totto in NYC, Menshu in SF, and other top spots. You can safely add Yokato to this upper echelon of sophisticated ramen. The noodles (thin) were excellent as was the tonkatsu broth. Not a lot of add-ons included, though you can add them on for a fee. But the basic was just so excellent that I can't ding them for it. Would love to see a touch more creative options, but that's just reaching for a problem. Also the karaage appetizer was great.Best ramen in Montreal.

This is the real deal!  The only thing I be they need to make this more like Tokyo is the ticket machine out front!Located on a quiet street that is almost all residential,we kept wondering if we were headed the right way, is a lovely bowl of ramen waiting for you. We entered and were greeted with a question, " do you only want ramen or do you want drinks?"  Both I said so they escorted us to next door to Ichiego.  I guess there might be a license issue.  But since we mainly had the ramen I'm putting this review here. We had both the tonkotsu and the spicy miso. Both were excellent. Very rich and yummy. If you are looking for lighter styles of ramen, probably not your place. But for rich porky goodness, then this is your place. Pork was flavorful, tender and rich.  The egg nicely done. You can customize a bit but I suggest going with normal and standards for your first time to check in comparison to your tastes. We also got some of the mackerel since we were on the izakya side.  Excellent but maybe a bit pricy.  But having some pickeled mackerel with kiwi and just barely torched turn out to be very tasty. Reasonable beers and interesting selection of saki. But prices on saki always depress me but what are you going to do about shipping and import issues?  Go now and enjoy!  I plan to go back before the end of my holiday.

Went there Friday for lunch and it's still as good as I remembered it! Had the veggie broth but I ordered karage chicken and the gobo fries(the best!) so...I inhaled the food and forgot to take pictures again.......next time!P.s. I should have ordered the extra egg....though it would had made me way too full!

If you don't want to wait for Ichigo Ichie next door, try Yokato - same food, shorter queue, quicker service. It only serves ramen, no booze, but MATE, THAT'S ALL YOU NEED BECAUSE THIS STUFF IS INCREDIBLE.Highly recommended: pork tonkotsu, extra egg, followed by green tea ice cream

Been there for lunch and had Ramen as well as Karagee (fried chicken) both were very good. The ambiance is nice and the place is clean. In the afternoon you can order the ramen and it's customizable, at night their isakaya is open and they don't serve ramen but seems like another great place to try.I recommend the Ramen with Pork Belly and load up on the fried garlic.
Service was awesome :)) The server was super friendly and funny. Him and the ramen made our day. All the staff say arigato gozaimasu after you leave, Great experience overall!

The cold winter months in Montreal are perfect a hot bowl of Ramen ! This is a cute little spot tucked away in the plateau that I got the chance to try out on a Friday night. Definitely show up early because there seems to always be a line anytime I pass by. The staff was friendly and the restaurant is very cozy and cute inside. The menu is a little paper where you pick out the items you want in your ramen (choice of a few beverages, no alcohol and a few types of ice cream to choose from for dessert). The prices were fair, not dirt cheap but not overly pricey either I ordered the thick noodles, with pork belly, corn seaweed and egg. They brought me the thin noodles instead but I'll forgive it because the soup was so rich, delicious, comforting and full of flavour! I was definitely not disappointed. We also had the ice cream (my boyfriend had the matcha ice cream and I had the sake ice cream) both were great not too sweet and really interesting fun flavour in the sake ice cream it was my favourite between the two. I highly recommend this place to any Ramen fan - enjoy !

Waited for more than 30 minutes in the freezing weather of Montreal for their Tonkotsu Ramen. Honestly I was really disappointed with their broth. I thought it was missing the "kick" so much so that I asked for crushed raw garlic (which they didn't have) and some salt. However, my companies did enjoy their bowl of ramen so maybe it's just a matter of preference.The chicken appetizer, though, was great. If I ever come here again, I'd order this dish and skip on the ramen bowl.

I tried the vegan ramen and it was really well balanced, had tons of veggies and the noodles were slightly chewy. I'm happy I discovered this place, I knew that it was great the moment I saw a line forming at the entrance.

Like all the other Japanese ramen, the broth was very thick. I chose the less salt but still got very thirsty after the meal. Since I was already very full with noodle and broth and appetizer, I couldn't quench my thirst with more water. Overall it is worth trying, the pork and egg is very special to my taste. The thick broth is not my favorite. There are four appetizers to choose from and we had three of them. The fried veggi roots is new to me. Very tender even after deep fried. The fried chicken and don(rice) are very good too. Price wise : a little expensive comparing to other place in downtown area, considering the dinning condition which is not very spacious.
Great service and lively ambiance. Menu to please everyone. You can dress up your ramen as you please. Loved the fried chicken, it's a must try!

I'll put it like this.. I've had ramen 4times this is so far the best one! The service is amazing. I've been the with a few Asian friends that ordered stuff I can't spell but tastes AMAZING !!! It's a must go if you are into Asian food
The soup was so rich and creamy! Definitely will go there again! They put a little bit wasabi in the salad and it tastes good. Recommend saké ice-cream as well.

My favourite ramen joint in Montreal ....I've pretty much eaten from their entire menu and everything is delicious and I would highly recommend them again.   Highlights: They have great free ramen toppings ...  like pink ginger and sesame seeds .   The ramen is always perfect and the broth is milky white and flavourful without being overly salty like many ramen joints.  They have amazing fried chicken and gobo fries.   I love this place!  My go to spot when I hit up montreal.

Most likely the best ramen in town. Having been to Japan recently, I came back to Montreal with the hunt for a ramen that comes close to what I tasted in Japan. And this place is likely where it comes closest.Located in a reclused corner, there are only few seats. The ambiance was nice and you get to see the kitchen, just like in Japan. There are only few choices for your ramen bowl, but don't let that deter you, the taste is really flavorful. The broth is also very thick, which is positive. The only downside though is the high price. But for the quality you get, it is worth it!

Visiting Montreal for the first time. And this was our first stop after 7.5 hours drive from PA. My entourage (5) and I were starving...I got the tonkotsu pork ($13) and I slurped everything down. The broth was perfect in which it was rich and savory. I checked off all the toppings (green onions, seafood, and 1/2 egg). Topped it off with garlic, chili oil, ginger, toasted sesame (free condiments placed on our table). So delicious! And I don't even like ramen like that. Well now I officially do ;) Thank you Yokato Yokabai!!The rest of my entourage all ordered the Kara-Miso Porc ($14), Chasu-Don ($5.50) and homemade Green Tea ice cream ($4). They raved about their dishes as well. Portion sizes were fair. We just wished there was more as we took our last bites.Service by Cecile Ngu was excellent. Very friendly and attentive.  Highly recommend.

It used to be on my to-do list..not anymore...I have visited several Japanese restaurants here in mtl. The amount of regular bowl is really small to me.... No thing special abt the taste. At least not as good as the comments (I personally don't like it) I won't recommend it to my Asian friends seriously. But given to it's high reputation, you may regret to not having had a meal here, so that you can have your own judge.
Amazing first experience as someone who was just being introduced to Ramen. Such a great atmosphere and really good food. Next time I'm in Montreal I will be visiting again.

It is difficult to find this place at first because it has two entrances and the indication at the door is confusing. There's always a lineup and we waited for 1 hour when we arrived there at 6PM. Reputed to be the best ramen place in Montreal, Yokato is one of the busiest Japanese restaurants I have ever seen in the city. The inside of the place is quite dim but has good vibes and their bar is less busy than the eatery. Their sake is nice and four of us shared a bottle.Their ramen, my god, is indeed worth the one hour wait. The soup is savoury and cooked for hours with pork bones. It's creamy and rich but not excessive. The handmade ramen noodles is chewy and heavenly. Pick reduced salt soup and the taste is just extremely well balanced, otherwise the regular salt level is a bit salty to my taste.An extra surprise was the homemade yuzu (Japeness citrus) sorbet, WOW WOW and WOW! Refreshing and balanced to perfection it is a Must try! I would go back just for the ice cream

As someone who tends to only* appreciate ramen in Japan or Hong Kong, I have to say that Yokato does a great job in creating an authentic ramen experience especially in Montreal. I always choose the less salty broth, as their tonkotsu is quite rich. It is very hearty and genuinely tasty. Their pork chashu is always great quality and well cooked (yum for meat lovers!).Because their tonkotsu soup is so rich and filling I would definitely wish that they provided some vinegar to cut the heaviness of the pork.

My never-ending quest for awesome ramen finally led me here, and I certainly wasn't disappointed.Generous portion of ramen with a good, tasty broth. I loved having the garnishes on the table so we could help ourselves. The noodles were chewy and delicious. I don't know if it's my favourite ramen in Montréal, but it's definitely top 3 so do try it.We also shared an order of what I consider to be the best karaage in town, seriously so tender, juicy, and perfectly fried! Would love to try their izakaya side just based on that.
Great ramen spot that seems super traditional. All of the broth options are really good and the service is fantastic. The ramen comes with a lot of pork so beware. I recommend the vegetable broth!
Went there 2 times, second time was much better than I tried first time. I love the 叉燒(dark one) this time, really tasty! Karage was also good!

Aperently the best ramen in mtl according to people?! I would call it descent and give a 3/5They only have one sort of meat pork broth,they used to have the chicken one but now it's gone. I took the least salty choice of  tonkotsu and it was okay while eating it,but omg i was so thirsty after leaving the restaurant....so there must have been lots of salt and msg!!!   The noodles were okay,nothing perticularly special. The soup was flavourful and fatty. Also took the gobo fries which was interesting,but a little bit overfried. the karage was not most,nor jucy,just a froed chicken and i have tasted better.The service was attentive,the waiting staff girls seems to be working super hard.It's also a good thing u just leave your name and they call u back when your table is ready.The service was a little bit confusing, i ordered extra noodles and karage,it only came at the end when i was almost done with my ramen.It is understandable though,busy saturday so i didn't go crazy about it.Bottom line,the place looks great and has a nice ambiance. the food is okay, i would say better than the ramens on st-cath. I would recommend this ramen place over the other ones. The izakaya ichigo ichie right next to it is cool too.

Sooooo good.Not much to say that hasn't already been said. We like ramen, and eat ramen everywhere we go... (various cities in North America, Asia - including Japan, and even Europe.. yep...). This was comparable to some great ramen we've had in Japan. The tonkotsu soup was super flavorful without being overly rich. Get the bamboo shoots and the spicy miso add on.

Came here on a rainy Sunday right at opening for dinner time. (5pm). No wait for a table, but the place immediately filled up. Definitely recommend getting here at opening to avoid the wait.I had the tonkotsu ramen with pork belly. The broth was flavourful, and the pork was cooked well. The portion size is good. I felt like the broth was a little one dimensional, and could have used some more seasoning and / or spice. Next time I'll try the spicy one.Biggest surprise was the homemade ice cream. The green tea was decent, but the sake flavoured ice cream was delicious. Just the right amount of creaminess, with a surprising kick of sake.

Great ramen place. I had the ramen with pork belly and it was really nice. The pork was very tender it was amazing. I had the thin noodles but probably the thicker would've been nicer. The thicker is more of the standard ramen noodle size. As a plus they actually make the noodles in house. The broth was good it was almost creamy which was cool. I had the regular salt content but might've been better if I had the more salty one bc tHats more of the standard ramen taste. I had the fried chicken, not bad. Would return.

Came here late at night on Friday but still had to wait over 30 min. Best thing to do is put your name on both side of the restaurant and cancel one when you get a seat. The two sides are basically the same (i think one side you can get alcohol)The food was mediocre.. definitely had much better ramens for cheaper.. was pretty disappointed that we waited so long for a meh dinner. We also got the karaage but they forgot about it. So it came after we were done with our ramen.

Came in around 10pm ish on a Friday night and the place was PACKED. Stating the obvious but of course there was a wait. I got super lucky since I was a one party and was able to be quickly seated at the bar. I still waited roughly 10-15 mins. but noticed that couples or groups of 3+ were definitely waiting 25-40 mins. The menu is short and sweet. You've got some apps but the rest of the menu is for you to order your own customized ramen. You get to select the type of noods, amount of broth, salt level and choose your toppings. I kept my ramen order pretty basic and I got my meal within no time. Broth was perfect. I loved that it wasn't too salty and the noods were good too. Staff members were friendly. I liked that I was able to get in and out quickly and head straight home to bed.

I get what all the hype is about now, at long last. The first two times I came to this place, I let them talk me into getting the pork broth with a bit of spicy kara-miso in it, and each time I was a bit disappointed. The broth was super tasty but I found it odd that it was so lukewarm instead of hot (maybe because of the miso paste), and I found the milky texture a bit off-putting. I could tell it wasn't bad, just not my thing, which bummed me out, because I've wanted a good ramen place for a while now. So, last time, I got the veggie broth with chicken, no kara-miso paste, and it was FANTASTIC, with just the kind of flavour profile I wanted, and a rich, clear broth served piping hot. Best ramen I've had in ages, maybe ever. The moral of the story: if this place doesn't grab you the first time, give it another shot and switch up your order. They're obviously very proud of their pork tonkotsu and spicy miso paste, but those aren't going to be to everyone's tastes. Besides, the prices are pretty good and the selection is quite small, so it's easy enough to experiment a little.

Was craving for ramen and decided to try this place as it had many good reviews. Went there around 1730 on a Wednesday evening, good ambiance, not too crowded. Unfortunately, place didn't have any highchair, we were disappointed as it meant we had to watch over our 15 months toddler while trying to eat our ramen.. we tried their booster but I was still distracted in watching over my son not sliding down the chair. Food was just ok. Also not many food option for kids.. ordered fried chicken plus 2 ramens. Their broth was creamy but very heavy. Meat was well cooked, flavourful and tender but their broth was a bit bland (had better ramen with better toppings). We thought it was overpriced, total of 50$ for ramens and fried chicken. It was good but would not return.

Don't let the line up deter you from going here.  Was in line for maybe 30 minutes on a long weekend and it was well worth the wait. Had the tonkotsu ramen with pork belly.  The broth is rich and creamy but not too heavy.  The pork belly was cooked to absolute perfection.  I love that they have roasted garlic, peanuts, spicy oil and picked ginger at the table for you to add your desired amount.  You can customize your ramen from the start to finish and I absolutely love that.The gobo (burdock fries) was a great starter, nice and crunchy with a spicy mayo.  The mayo isn't that spicy but it had good flavor.  The karaage (fried chicken) appetizer was good but nothing extraordinary. Ended with their homemade ice cream.  We were a group of people so we tried all the flavors.  The green tea is by far the best one, followed by the yuzu, sake and then vanilla.  Great pricing too! appetizer, ramen with extras and ice cream for $24 before tip.  Reasonable dinner price for the amount of food you get.Staff was super efficient, friendly and professional. I know I will be craving and dreaming of their ramen and it's the only thing that'll get me through the cold winter months to come in Montreal. I will be coming back again and again.

Didn't live up to expectations, but still quite good.I came for lunch on a cloudy Wednesday, around 1pm. There were plenty of empty seats, no wait at all. My server was friendly and the restaurant had free wi-fi.The menu is short and simple, you check off the items you want on a slip of paper. There aren't many options for different types of broth, or toppings. I ordered the regular tonkotsu, with corn added. My choice of 1/2 egg, 1 piece of seaweed, onions, and 2 pieces of chasu was included in the base price.The broth was rich and creamy, it paired well with the texture of the thin noodles. The chasu was tender and cooked perfectly. Downsides were that the egg was subpar, and the portions were a bit small; but I left satisfied.It's worth checking out, but perhaps not worth waiting an hour in line- as other reviewers have described.

I like this place. Is it just me or Montreal food taste so goooood, but so expensive. At least the currency exchange haha! The pork is a little fatty so if you don't like that then get chicken. My friend left half his pork because he thought it was too fatty. In that moment, we all said "how can you waste meat??"Service is a little slower, but many places I go were like that and they just opened plus there was a huge table ahead of us.

My favorite ramen place of all time! Great place for ramen if you like rich and creamy soup. Love their Tonkotsu broth and I always take an extra egg. Both the pork and the teriyaki chicken are good but haven't try the vegetarian one yet. The Kaarage (fried chicken) is also very good. Enough to share for 2 people. A peaceful place for lunch but can get busy at night and have a line up.

Wandered into the restaurant as it was the only thing open in the area. Make sure to sit in the ramen only area if you want to be seated quickly.As for the ramen, the broth was amazing and flavorful. It was a bit mild for me, so the addition of spicy miso was necessary. There's a lot of noodles in the bowl so I ended up being entirely full.
Stopped by this ramen shop before I headed off to the airport. It was the best chicken karaage I have ever had ! Ramen broth and portion were good and it was not too salty. Highly recommended :)

Went here on a weekday and got in right away after they opened. This is the best ramen place I've tried in Montreal but not in my top 5 in North America. Overall it was not bad to be honest, took one star out cause I am a soup person and soup kinda disappointed me. I always have tonkotsu wherever I go, and soup here is really creamy but somehow saltless even I ordered normal--really porky but feel something is missing. I didn't get much soup in bowl either.Other than that noodle is really fine which I liked it, I ordered extra bamboo shoot and lotus root and came with good amount; my husband ordered extra pork and he got a bowl of ramen full of pork--really soft and fatty chashu! Homemade yuzu ice cream was great, really refreshing after ramen.I will still go if I am craving for ramen but I won't give up on looking for better ramen spot in town.--Update: their chashu don was great!

This is a really awesome spot. Great for a cute date night. Professional staff and nice menu.The spot was full so we went they recommended we wait at the bar  while waiting for our table to be free. The drinks menu is so creative and delicious.  We also ordered little pieces of fried chicken with wasabi dipping. Soo good. Once we got our seat to have our soup We chose what ramen we wanted on a piece of paper. U choose your broth, (3 options) so it really doesn't overwhelm you with decisions, then you choose the protein and the toppings,and the extras. The soup was tasty and a bit creamy. Noodles made fresh. Will for sure be going back there soon.

Best meal we had in Montreal. The ambience is typical of a Japanese restaurant.  It is a small space filled with lots of hungry people.  There are lanterns hanging and traditional Japanese images painted in the halls and near the bathrooms.   We waited in line for about 45 minutes before being seated which was to be expected on a Saturday night.We ordered burdock fries and fried chicken for starters and both were delicious.  The fried chicken was battered and fried and topped with seaweed, spices and sauces.As for the ramen-oh my god-it was incredible.  If someone were to ask me what the best meal was that I enjoyed in a restaurant, I wouldn't pause for a second before excitedly telling them about this drool-worthy, slap-ya-mama good meal.  Holy cow!!! The noodles were buttery and creamy.  The broth was full of flavor and all of the veggies and meats were cooked to perfection.  If I were in Montreal longer, I'd be back as soon as possible.

Best ramen I've had in Canada, and top 3 outside of Japan.This ramen shop feels authentic...it's tiny and you can see the chefs cooking the ramen in front of you. They even have the big wood handled soup spoons! Service was lovely.The menu is simple but there are also desserts and other small dishes. If you don't read French, just flip the menu over for the English side. It took us a minute to figure that out lol.Another tip...if there's a line make sure to get your name and party count on the clipboard. Squeeze through to the cash register to find it hanging underneath. Oh yeah, and there's free wifi!The restaurant is connected to a tapas restaurant under the same owner. I was told you can only order ramen in the ramen side of the building.The ramen itself was excellent. We both ordered the tonkatsu broth (they also have spicy miso and veg). I chose chicken instead of pork or veg topping, with regular green onion and less sodium. You get half an egg for free. In hindsight, I would have ordered double noodles and regular sodium but I still enjoyed every bite! Other toppings are also available for a charge.The noodles are thin and go well with the broth, which is flavorful and not too fatty. The half egg was delicious and a perfect portion. I also added some of the chili oil to taste and pickled ginger from the condiments jars (wasn't sure if that was what it was meant for but I enjoyed that extra kick).I would definitely recommend to anyone in town wanting some ramen!

After a positive experience, at yokato yakobai, we decided to got here again.  We noticed that they had expanded considerably in terms of their seating and menu.  The place looks more like an izakaya now.  Serving Japanese tapas and has huge communal tables.The funny thing after paying and leaving the place, we noticed we were eating at a different place.  It's called ichigo ichie, apparently, yokato yokabai and ichigo ichie are joint businesses.  We had the ramen, chicken karrage and curry potato croquettes.  Everything was all good except for the yuzu ice cream.  The last time we went, the ice cream was memorable.  This time the ice cream tasted like fluffy egg whites.  My cousins said:  " the ice cream does not even melt!" :)

Ever since coming back from Japan, I've been craving ramen noodle for so long and when I came across this place, I didn't expect it to be as good but oh man it HIT THE SPOT when you add the spicy paste. They have the vegetarian broth option which is sooo nice since most ramen places in Montreal only have meat broth. Loved it!!

After all the hype about this place I decided to give it a try. It was my first time so I opted for the chicken tonkotsu and karaage.The karaage was perfectly crisp and the sauce on it was greatNow for the ramen: I honestly thought it was flavorless, it pretty much tasted like cream. The broth was extremely underseasoned. The only redeeming factor was the sweet chicken in it which was good.The service was very friendly but overall I would not come back here.

Yokato Yokabai is a small Ramen restaurant.  This side of the restaurant is unlicensed, so you can't order alcohol.  The seating involves high stools in a small area, so if you have accessibility issues, this restaurant may not work for you.  I didn't use the bathroom, so I can't speak to their genderedness.  The restaurant gets QUITE busy and doesn't accept reservations.The menu offers standard Ramen offerings, mostly Tonkotsu and Kara-miso offerings.  I THINK the Kara-miso is vegetarian, but I'm not 100% sure.  Anyways, Yokato Yokabai served some of the best Ramen I've ever had in my life.  The stock was so creamy and filing, the noodles, made fresh on site, were delicious and tasty and the selection of toppings was excellent.   I am still dreaming of this Ramen.  I want to go back to Montreal just to eat more of Yokato Yokabai.

It has been while since I came here. Still the best ramen in town. Luckily, we went early enough to avoid long line ups. I strongly recommend to try the appetizer of fried burdock roots. Unfortunately, price has increased and portions decreased. I usually like to take thick noodle, but now it has become an extra. There is even fee for more broth. Still, won't be able to resist the good taste here. I will definitely come back.

After moving back to Montreal from Vancouver, I had a huge craving for some authentic, rich, Japanese ramen. I usually go for the miso based ramen soup because it's less heavy, but Yokato only serves their tonkatsu broth. It is thick and creamy, and probably the closest thing to Vancouver ramen I've had in Montreal. My only complaint is that I wish they'd serve more broth with their ramen. They only fill up the broth halfway up to where the ramen noodles are, so because of the broth's thickness, the broth ends up almost like a sauce instead.
